Published by American Chemical Society 2025 The Authors https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This article is licensed under CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 The design and development
of controlled-release drug systems represent
a pivotal area of research in modern pharmaceutical technologies.
An ideal drug release system should precisely regulate both the release
rate and duration of the drug, thereby enhancing therapeutic efficacy,
reducing dose frequency, and minimizing adverse effects. In recent
years, nanomaterials have become integral to drug delivery, with nanotechnology
focusing on the design and application of nanomaterials. Metal–organic
frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as promising drug carriers due to their
high specific surface area, tunable porosity, and selective adsorption
capabilities. However, MOFs often exhibit limited thermal stability,
susceptibility to degradation, and sensitivity to acidic and basic
conditions. To address these limitations, the integration of MOFs
with polymers has shown promising potential. MOF-polymer composites
can enhance drug loading capacity, improve drug solubility, and provide
greater thermal stability while mitigating adverse reactions. Polyurethane
(PU) is widely employed as a drug carrier due to its unique chemical
properties and biodegradability. However, PU alone may lead to issues
such as burst drug release and vulnerability to fungal colonization.
Consequently, MOF-PU composites have garnered significant attention
as advanced drug carriers, leveraging the synergistic properties of
both materials to overcome their individual limitations. This review
explores the definition, preparation methods, advantages, and application
domains of MOF-PU composites, with a particular emphasis on their
role as drug carriers. The objective is to provide a comprehensive
reference for ongoing and future research into the utilization of
MOF-PU composites in drug delivery systems. consistently prioritized healthcare advancements,
reflecting a widespread societal interest in health and well-being.
Within this field, drug delivery systems (DDSs) are of paramount importance
due to their potential for simplified, rapid, and convenient therapeutic
administration. However, conventional DDSs often suffer from limitations
including poor target specificity, cytotoxicity, low drug solubility,
and short in vivo half-life, collectively compromising therapeutic
efficacy. Metal–organic frameworks
(MOFs) are a class of porous nanomaterials
constructed from metal ions or clusters coordinated by organic linkers.  Polyurethane (PU) is a widely employed
polymer in drug delivery
applications due to its advantageous properties, including facile
synthesis, biocompatibility, bioinertness, and biodegradability.    2 4 2 4 Table E. coli 1 Types of MOFs Used for Developing

of lithium sulfur battery separators
(∼10 –3 Battery separator
material  This article
is a narrative review aimed at sorting out milestone
research and recent key literature in the field through selective
analysis MOF@PU The development trajectory and exploration of future
challenges. The data collection covers literature from 2010 to 2025
to ensure the inclusion of foundational research in the field, while
reflecting the latest developments brought about by technological
innovations in the past five years. 2 Advantages
and Disadvantages of MOFs Metal–organic frameworks
(MOFs) have garnered significant
attention due to their structural diversity and potential applications
across various fields related to porous materials. 2.1 Well-Defined Structure MOFs are a
class of crystalline porous materials with well-defined pore structures
and adjustable pore diameters, formed through the self-assembly of
metal clusters/ions and organic ligands via coordination bonds. Unlike
some traditional materials, the well-defined crystal structures of
MOFs can be determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, providing
direct evidence for investigating related chemical reaction mechanisms
and structure–property relationships. 2.2 Structural Diversity The variety
of MOF materials can be tailored by selecting appropriate metal ions
and organic ligands under specific reaction conditions. The vast number
of organic ligands and metal ions allows for the synthesis of a diverse
range of MOF materials. Furthermore, the incorporation of binary or
even multiple organic ligands or metal ions in the reaction system
offers virtually unlimited possibilities for MOF synthesis. Currently,
over 80,000 MOF structures are cataloged in the Cambridge Crystallographic
Data Centre (CCDC), and the theoretical number of possible MOFs is
essentially limitless. 2.3 Designability and Modifiability Functional
building blocks can be strategically selected or designed to directly
synthesize MOF materials with specific functionalities. Alternatively,
different classes of functional groups can be introduced via postsynthetic
modification (PSM) for targeted performance modulation, enabling the
preparation of MOF materials tailored for specific applications. 2.4 Ultra-High Specific Surface
Area and Multi-Porous
Structure MOFs exhibit ultrahigh specific surface areas,
pore volumes, and porosities. 2 3 2.5 Biocompatibility The metal ion centers
in MOF materials can be selected from biocompatible elements such
as Fe, Al, Ca, and Mg. The organic ligands can be chosen from biological
organic molecules such as condensates and adenine, in addition to
common carboxylic acids and nitrogen-containing heterocyclic organic
ligands. The combination of these components under appropriate reaction
conditions can be directed toward the construction of bio-MOFs, which
have been identified as promising materials in the biomedical field.  However, there are still some key defects in the practical
application of MOFs, which limit their large-scale commercial development,
mainly including the following aspects: 2.6 Insufficient
Chemical Stability Most
MOFs are prone to structural collapse in water, acid, alkali, or high
temperature environments, especially those containing metal nodes
such as Zn and Cu, which are prone to hydrolysis, leading to pore
structure damage and affecting their long-term performance. 2.7 Low Mechanical Strength MOFs typically
exhibit brittle crystal structures, poor mechanical strength, and
are prone to fracture under pressure or shear forces, making it difficult
to directly process into flexible devices or industrial grade adsorbent
materials. 2.8 The Conductivity
Is Generally Poor Although some
MOFs (such as Ni-(HITP) 2 2.9 Large Scale Preparation
and Cost Issues The synthesis of MOFs typically requires
high-purity organic ligands
and metal salts, and the solvothermal method is time-consuming and
energy consuming, making it difficult to achieve low-cost, large-scale
production. In addition, the high cost of raw materials for some MOFs,
such as rare metals, further raises the threshold for industrial applications. 2.10 Difficulty in Processing
and Forming MOFs mostly exist in powder form and are difficult
to directly process
into thin films, fibers, or bulk materials. Therefore, polymer composites
or substrate loading are needed to enhance processability, but some
porosity and active sites may be sacrificed. 3 Advantages and Disadvantages of Polyurethanes Polyurethanes (PUs) constitute a significant class of thermoplastic
and thermoset polymers, characterized by their customizable mechanical,
thermal, and chemical properties through the reaction of diverse polyols
and polyisocyanates. In biomedical
applications, PUs has demonstrated significant potential
due to their excellent biocompatibility, bacteriostatic properties,
mechanical performance, adhesion characteristics, and cost-effectiveness.
Their adaptability is further enhanced through blending, remolding,
and modification with other polymers to meet specific application
requirements. For instance, Kim et al. 4 Preparation
of MOF-PU Composites Metal–organic framework-polyurethane
(MOF-PU) composites
are synthesized through diverse methodologies, including solvothermal,
hydrothermal, sonochemical, and in situ synthesis techniques ( Figure 1 The illustration of the preparation of MOF-PU composites
using
these techniques: solvothermal method. The solvothermal method is a closed-system technique that employs
organic or nonaqueous solvents under controlled temperatures and pressures.
Although this method is straightforward and offers precise control
over reaction conditions, it is associated with several drawbacks,
including high temperatures, high pressures, and prolonged reaction
times. Hydrothermal synthesis involves chemical
reactions in aqueous solutions
under high temperatures and pressures. This method is widely recognized
for its advantages, including high reactant activity, precise control
over solution or interfacial reactions, the formation of metastable
and unique condensed phases, reduced air pollution, and low energy
consumption. The sonochemical method
involves applying high-energy ultrasound
(20 kHz to 10 MHz) to irradiate materials, which enhances their crystallinity
and growth rate, resulting in energy-efficient products. This technique
avoids the need for high temperatures, high pressures, and long reaction
times. However, the instability of the acoustochemical effect and
the immaturity of ultrasound-assisted technology in chemical production
pose significant technical and equipment challenges that require further
research.  In situ synthesis
involves chemical reactions between different
elements or compounds under specific conditions, generating one or
more ceramic phase particles within a metal matrix. This process enhances
the properties of the metal alloy.  2 5 Application
of MOF-PU Composites Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have
shown broad application prospects
in gas adsorption, catalysis, sensing, and drug delivery due to their
highly adjustable pore structure, large specific surface area, and
diverse functional properties. However, the mechanical strength, chemical
stability, and functional integration of traditional MOFs still face
challenges, limiting their practical applications in complex environments.
In recent years, by combining polymer (PU) with MOFs PU@MOFs Hybrid
materials provide new ideas for solving these problems. The introduction
of PU not only enhances the mechanical toughness and environmental
stability of MOFs, but also endows the material with dynamic responsiveness,
selective permeation, or multifunctional integration through synergistic
effects at the molecular level. For example, the flexible segments
of PU can effectively alleviate the brittleness problem of MOFs, while
its rich functional groups provide additional active sites or interface
interactions for MOFs, further expanding the design dimensions of
materials. At present, PU@MOFs composite materials have demonstrated
unique advantages in fields such as flexible electronics, intelligent
coatings, efficient separation membranes, and biomedical research,
becoming a hot topic in interdisciplinary research. 5.1 Application
of MOF-PU Composites as Drug Carriers
in the Pharmaceutical Field Pharmaceutical drug delivery
systems, such as ophthalmic drops, oral administration, intravenous
injections, and localized treatments, often fail to precisely target
drugs or accurately control dosages. Metal–organic framework
(MOF) nanoparticles have emerged as promising candidates for drug
transport systems due to their large surface area and highly tunable
properties.    5.1.1 Application of UiO-67-PU Composite Material
as Drug Carrier in Pharmaceutical Field Traditional eye medications,
typically administered as eye drops, often suffer from low drug utilization
and limited effectiveness in treating eye diseases. Nano drug delivery
systems offer a promising alternative by enhancing bioavailability
and enabling effective drug penetration into deeper tissues, potentially
revolutionizing conventional drug delivery methods. UiO-67, a potential
nanocarrier for intraocular delivery of brimonidine tartrate in chronic
glaucoma treatment, exhibits excellent properties due to its large
tetrahedral and octahedral cages within microporous or mesoporous
networks.  Figure Figure Figure Figure 2 (a) Liquid-phase
adsorption isotherms of brimonidine tartrate at
298 K in accordance with the Langmuir equation (dashed line). 5.1.2 Application of UiO-66-PU
Composites as Drug
Carriers in the Field of Medicine UiO-66 is an ideal candidate
for delivering anticancer drugs like doxorubicin (DOX) and paclitaxel
due to its high stability in aqueous and blood environments, as well
as its excellent biocompatibility. Figure Figure Figure 3 (a) X-ray
diffraction spectra of UiO-66, UiO-66-DOX and UiO-66-FA. 5.1.3 Other MOF-PU Composites are Used as Drug
Carriers in the Pharmaceutical Field Recent studies have
explored advanced drug delivery systems using MOF-based nanocomposites
for glioblastoma treatment. Bazzazzadeh et al. g Figure g Figure Figure    4 (a) Cell viability of
the synthesized nanofibers after treatment
with U-87 MG glioblastoma cells. Luo et al. Figure Figure Figure 5 (a) Scanning electron

image) light stimulation. (c) Illustration of in vitro drug release
from DOX/poly­(DH-Se/PEG/PPG urethane)@MOF nanocomposites under light
irradiation. (d) In vitro cumulative drug release behavior of DOX/poly­(DH-Se/PEG/PPG
urethane)@MOF nanocomposites under light irradiation and no light
conditions. 5.1.4 The Application of MOF-PU Microcapsules
or Thermogels as Drug Carriers in the Pharmaceutical Field The development of advanced drug delivery systems has been driven
by the need to improve therapeutic efficacy and address the complexity
of biochemical processes. Continuous drug administration has revolutionized
disease treatment over the years. However, the complexity of biochemical
processes indicates that therapeutic efficacy can be improved by targeting
multiple biological pathways or leveraging synergistic effects.  Recent advancements in MOF-based composites
have enabled innovative drug delivery systems with enhanced functionality
and controlled release capabilities. Deleu et al. Figure Figure Figure  5.2 Application of MOF-PU Composite Material as
Drug Carrier in Agricultural Field The widespread use of
pesticides has raised significant environmental and health concerns,
necessitating innovative solutions to reduce their impact. Pesticides
threaten ecosystems, nontarget organisms, and human health, leading
to issues like pest resistance and resource wastage.   Recent studies have demonstrated the potential of MOF-based composites
in addressing environmental challenges, such as pesticide adsorption
and extraction. Chen et al. 2 Figure Figure Figure 6 (a) Synthesis and use of MOF encapsulated in
photounstable capsules. 7 (a) Scanning electron microscope morphology of sponge,
coated sponge
held at 70 °C for 4 h and elemental spectrum of ODSOSS/TiO 2 5.3 Application of MOF-PU Polymeric Material as
Carrier in Medical Devices MOF-based composites have shown
significant potential in biomedical applications, particularly in
nitric oxide (NO) generation and surface modification for medical
devices. Melvin et al. 3 4 3 8 3 tris   Figure Figure 2+ 8 (a) Hypothetical modeling of NO production from MOF composite
with
high MOF loading and low PU concentration and low MOF loading and
high PU concentration, both affecting NO production. MOF-PU composites have been further explored for
their potential
in medical device coatings, with a focus on compatibility and antimicrobial
properties. Vornholt et al. Figure Pseudomonas aeruginosa 5.4 MOF-PU Composites are Used as Carriers in
Other Fields PU-based composites have been extensively studied
for their versatile applications, ranging from flame retardancy to
CO 2  Figure 2 2 2 2 Figure 9 (a) Possible flame retardant mechanisms
for TPU/ZIF-67@MXene composites. 6 Summarizing and Looking Forward The field
of biomedicine has increasingly turned to nanotechnology
and MOF-based composites to address the limitations of traditional
therapeutic drugs, such as low bioavailability, severe adverse effects,
and rapid elimination from the body.    The complexity
of the organism necessitates a comprehensive understanding
of the introduced materials. Currently, there is limited information
available regarding the mechanisms of various pathways of MOF-PU composites
within the organism. Additionally, the precise pharmacokinetics of
these composites remain undetermined. These limitations significantly
restrict the application of MOF-PU composites as carriers in drug
delivery systems. MOF materials are typically produced as powders,
which poses significant
challenges for their application in large-scale production. These
challenges include limited mechanical strength, insufficient chemical
and abrasion resistance, mass transfer limitations, and poor handling
properties. As a result, the systematic synthesis of MOF-PU composites
has become a critical area of research to address these limitations. MOF-PU composites are typically synthesized under high temperatures
and pressures, and these complex conditions significantly limit their
widespread practical applications. To address this, developing synthesis
strategies with mild conditions, as well as green and low-cost approaches,
has become a critical research focus. Furthermore, the effect of the
reaction environment on the surface properties of the composites requires
further investigation to optimize their performance. The development
of MOF-PU matrix composites is still in its early
stages. A comprehensive understanding of the relationship between
their preparation, structure, and application is essential for establishing
criteria to select appropriate methods for creating functionally oriented
materials. Despite the challenges in developing MOF-PU matrix composites,
the incorporation of polyurethane (PU) has significantly expanded
the applications of MOFs, particularly as drug carriers in the pharmaceutical
field and beyond. This review focuses on the preparation methods,
advantages, and drug carrier applications of MOF-PU composites. These
composites are designed to optimize key properties for biopharmaceutical
applications, including drug delivery mode, release rate, and utilization
rate. The development of MOF-PU-based composites holds immense potential
for advancing biomedical technology, especially in drug delivery systems,
and could lead to transformative breakthroughs that enhance human
life. The authors gratefully acknowledge support from
the Science and Technology Fund Project of Guizhou (no. Qian Ke He
Pingtai Rencai-CXTD [2022]002), Guizhou Provincial Key Project of

and the Science and Technology Planning Project of Guizhou Province
(no. QKHZC [2022]132). The authors
declare no competing financial interest. Anh
